Award.AwardTitle: Applications of derived algebraic geometry to problems in Hodge and Lie theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The overarching theme of the current project is applying techniques and intuitions from the newly developed field of derived algebraic geometry to solve or rephrase classical problems in algebraic geometry and complex geometry. Two main topics are proposed. The first one involves studying the semi-regularity map introduced by Spencer Bloch in 1972 from the point of view of topological conformal field theory. The main intuition is that the semi-regularity map should be a part of the so-called open-closed map that appears in the study of open-closed topological conformal field theories. The second topic involves studying the relationship between the PI's recent result with Dima Arinkin on the existence of a fibration structure on the derived self-intersection of a submanifold and the 1988 proof of Deligne and Illusie of the algebraic Hodge theorem.

The 19th and 20th century saw the development of Lie theory and Hodge theory, two of the most influential areas of modern mathematics. These theories have had direct influence on our understanding of quantum physics and related fields. Derived algebraic geometry is a new and exciting field of mathematics, lying at the interface of algebraic geometry and algebraic topology. The work in this project will enhance our understanding of the newly developed ideas of derived algebraic geometry, by studying applications to classical problems in Hodge theory and algebraic geometry. Applications to other fields are expected, with a number of projects containing applications to problems in Lie theory being included.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Algebraic geometry is the study of spaces defined by common zeros of polynomial equations. Some of these spaces, called Calabi-Yau manifolds, have found special significance in recent years in the study of particle physics, specifically in string theory and mirror symmetry.

In this project the PI studied several geometric and algebraic aspects of algebraic varieties, with a special focus on Calabi-Yau spaces. In one direction the PI found a new proof of the Hodge theorem, which allows one to define numerical invariants that distinguish algebraic varieties (Hodge numbers).

In another direction the PI investigated an example of a pair of Calabi-Yau manifolds of dimension three which, although they are different, are related by a relationship called derived equivalence. The existence of this derived equivalence implies that the Hodge numbers (and a more refined invariant called Hodge structure) of these spaces are the same. This showed that there is no hope of recognizing which specific Calabi-Yau space one has only by knowing the Hodge structure, thereby providing a counterexample to the so-called Torelli statement for Calabi-Yau threefolds.

In yet another direction the PI studied invariants of Calabi-Yau manifolds which are a generalization of the process of counting curves of a special type (holomorphic) in these spaces. Specifically the PI investigated a general construction proposed by Kevin Costello approximately 12 years ago, and was able to compute these invariants for the first non-trivial family of Calabi-Yau spaces, the family of elliptic curves.

The above works are joint with collaborators Marton Hablicsek, Dima Arinkin, Junwu Tu, Damien Calaque, Lev Borisov, Alex Perry, Johanna Knapp, and Eric Sharpe.
